awd_titl_txt: Investigation of Interface Structure-Property Relationship of Transition-Metal Oxides by in-Situ Materials Growth with Atomic Precision
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract: 
Future electronics will require novel materials and material interfaces. This project combines material growth with characterization to construct interface structures with atomic-scale precision. Such materials and interfaces provide new and often unexpected functionalities which can be utilized in future electronic devices. The broad goal of this work is to develop the science and technology arising at interfaces of this class of novel materials.  The research team intends to advance the fundamental design principles, which can in turn inspire the creation of new electronic and magnetic states for technological applications.  Furthermore, a significant product of this endeavor is to integrate material growth, characterization and design into a research and educational program for the training of the future science and technology workforce that meets new challenges in this technology-driven society.  Both graduate and undergraduate students are involved in material fabrication and characterization efforts.    

Technical Abstract:
The focus of this project lies in the novel proximity effects and related exciting structure-property relationship of novel ferromagnet-superconductor junctions.  By taking  advantage of the project's in-situ growth and characterization capability, this research team intends to uncover the structure-property relationship of the novel interfaces of transition metal oxides.  Specifically, by exploiting  expertise in creating atomically sharp interfaces between half-metallic manganites or ordinary ferromagnetic oxide films and unconventional superconductors, the team aims to resolve the outstanding issue of realizing long-range spin-polarized supercurrent, as well as determining the correlation between ferromagnetic layer structure and the coherent length of spin-polarized supercurrent by varying ferromagnetic layer thickness. Furthermore, the ability to  achieve in-situ growth and characterization with atomic precision allows addressing several fundamental issues in metal-superconductor junctions, including atomic-level controlled tuning of barrier transparency on Andreev reflection, and conceptual validation of triplet Josephson junctions.

por.por_cntn:
This project has generated several outcomes on both development of human resources, education and educational outreach, and scientific research. These outcomes are summarized in the followings:

Broader Impact:

New generations of electronic devices with correlated electron materials will involve the fabrication of thin films, superstructures, and heterojunctions. Virtually all the development of electronic devices begins with an understanding of electronic and magnetic structures of interfaces and junctions. By combining material growth with comprehensive characterization to construct interface structures with requisite atomic-scale precision and reveal the emergent material functionalities, the research of this project has discovered few technologically potential material properties, including possible spin-transport for spintronic devices, enhanced interface superconductivity and topologically protected surface plasmons for technologically applications with lees energy-dispassion.   

Another product of this endeavor is integrating material growth, characterization, and design into a transformative research and educational program for the training of the future science and technology (S&T) workforce that will meet new challenges in this technology-driven society. The funding has supported three Ph.D. students through research assistantships and an undergraduate student, including on Ph.D. thesis. The program also helped training two postdocs, one becoming an assistant professor and the other having strong expertise as scanning transmission microscopy and spectroscopy. Furthermore, the project helped establishing an education and educational outreach program through PI?s close collaboration with the colleagues in condensed matter physics and materials sciences at Louisiana State University. The activities include weekly-based condensed matter physics seminar organized by students, undergraduate student participation in materials physics research, as well as open house activities and lab tours for the enhancement of materials physics education to local high school students and teachers (see attached Fig. 1).

Intellectual Merit:  

Overwhelming evidence shows that fascinating and unexpected phenomena emerge at the interfaces between, or ultrathin films of, many transition-metal oxides, though the origin is still fiercely contested.  In many cases, controlling the quality of interfaces and films of these complex materials is an indispensable step toward the understanding. By taking the advantage of our in-situ growth and characterization capability, we have accomplished several research results, which enhance the understanding of the structure-property relationship of the novel interfaces of transition metal oxides. The major scientific outcomes include:

1. By growing atomically defined interface between ferromagnetic half-metal and unconventional superconductor, we produced a platform for potential spin-polarized transport (See Fig. 2 for the atomically resolved image of the fabricated interface).

2. We reveal the role of disorder and electron-electron correlation in the metal-to-insulator transition with reduced dimensionality (film thickness) in a prototype metallic oxide.

3. We discovered a topologically protected surface plamsmon mode from the excitations of Dirac electrons in the topological surface state of a three-dimensional topological insulator. In sharp contrast with theoretical prediction, this mode has significantly lower energy than that within the continuous medium excitation picture, indicating the existence of a bosonic coupling. Probably, the mode is dressed by an acoustic phonon due to strong electron-lattice interactions.

4. We demonstrated that the polaron-polaron interaction is likely the origin of the enhanced Cooper pairing for the interface superconductivity between single-layered FeSe and oxide substrate. The electric field associated with the high-energy surface Fuch-Kliewer (F-K) phonons of oxide substrate penetrates into the FeSe layer, resulting in a strong interfacial electron-boson coupling thus responsible for the superconductivity enhancement.

5. Using a rare existing single crystal of polar metal, a metal but exhibiting ferroelectric (FE) behavior, we revealed that itinerant electrons existing in the system strongly renormalize the FE ordering through the screening of lattice, thus behaving unusual FE phase transition. The results indicate a strong coupling between phonons and electrons in the system, thus challenging the Anderson/Blount?s original idea that a 2nd-order FE transition can occur in metals only if itinerant electrons have a very weak or even zero coupling with a soft phonon.
